questions.neutral: Is it always this quiet when you come in?

hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?
Analog photography still treating you right?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It usually is. People keep to themselves lately.
I just relax here a bit, fold some paper for the table sometimes.
Hobby helps pass the time. Not much else to say.
Since the broadcasts, I guess I do it less.
Quieter than before the testimony fallout.
I fold origami—tiny models. It keeps my hands busy.
Some weeks, I bring them here. Not now, too risky.
Harder to focus these days with all the checks.
One’s still in my bag, unfinished since the last ID scan.
It's quieter everywhere, after those ghost stories blew up.
I fold origami. Used to, I mean. Paper, cranes, foxes—usually late.
Helps with the static in my head. Like sorting data, but safer.
I tried working on a modular piece last week here, but got distracted.
Last security sweep, I nearly left my model behind.
Still, folding keeps me coming back—habit, I guess.
It’s calm, which I don’t mind. Feels like my kitchen before the news broke.
Folding origami is what I do—tiny animals, tessellations.
I haven’t brought any paper lately. Too much surveillance.
Once, I’d leave a crane as a sort of secret tip.
During the ghost broadcasts I ripped one crane by accident. Couldn’t focus.
Now, sometimes I just fold napkins here, quick and sloppy.
I guess things don’t settle right in my mind unless I fold.
Quiet’s safer than chatter, especially these weeks. Makes it easier to just… fold.
I’m an origami obsessive—models from whatever scraps I can find. Old habit from the Directorate.
Used to leave a paper fox on my table every Thursday, a small ritual.
But after those ghost testimonies started, I stash paper instead of displaying the folds.
Security teams stopped me at my block last week. They saw my hands were ink-stained.
Now my folds are rushed—creases messy, no focus. It’s not just the news, it’s knowing they watch.
Last month someone found a torn tessellation I’d left. Asked if it was a code.
I keep folding. Even when it’s tense. Especially then.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Managed to fold one last week.
Not easy lately with all the inspections around.
Blocks are active after those broadcasts... makes things tense.
Just paper, though. Nothing important.
Does help pass the time. Sometimes.
I did. Just a crane or two, nothing fancy.
Guess it's harder to focus now.
Security checks in my block distract me, especially after those ghost testimonies.
Every crease feels rushed lately.
I keep my hobby private now.
Feels safer that way.
Made one crane a few nights back.
Used to fold a whole flock before all this tension.
Since the ghost stories aired, my building’s had constant interruptions.
I hear inspectors moving through the halls and lose my train of thought.
The paper feels less like an escape now, more like a risk.
Still, it’s my routine. Helps me process things.
Sometimes I hide the finished ones in case of searches.
Yeah, I still fold them—just slower, and only at home now.
It used to be meditative, you know? Cranes, swans, modular pieces if I had time.
But with all these late-night checks after that leak, I can't relax.
Last week, I froze halfway through a model when I heard an inspection on my floor.
I actually hid my paper stash. Silly, but... they flag anything unusual now.
It’s strange how even harmless habits feel suspect.
Folding is just muscle memory—my way to keep steady.
Feels like the system notices everything these days.
Definitely—though I finish fewer cranes than before.
After the ‘ghost’ testimonies were broadcast, the mood in my block changed overnight.
When the first search team came by, I actually crumpled up a project mid-fold.
Used to work on complex tessellations at the table, no worries about who might see.
Now, every sound in the corridor makes me hesitate or stop altogether.
Even hiding the paper feels like a little rebellion. Shows you how weird things have gotten.
Sometimes, I think about tracking stress by how many cranes turn out crooked.
To be honest, folding helps me keep perspective on the chaos.
It’s odd—the system scores people for behavior, but it can’t measure what quiet work like this does for someone’s mind.
